001package io.github.ai4ci.config.setup;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004
005import org.davidmoten.hilbert.HilbertCurve;
006import org.davidmoten.hilbert.SmallHilbertCurve;
007import org.immutables.value.Value;
008
009import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonIgnore;
010import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonDeserialize;
011import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonSerialize;
012
013import io.github.ai4ci.abm.Abstraction;
014
015/**
016 * Configuration used during model setup and initialisation.
017 *
018 * <p>
019 * Main purpose: encapsulate the parameters and strategies required to create
020 * agents and construct their contact network at the start of a simulation.
021 * Features include:
022 * <ul>
023 * <li>the number of initial imports used to seed an outbreak;</li>
024 * <li>a pluggable network generation strategy via
025 * {@link NetworkConfiguration};</li>
026 * <li>a pluggable demographic strategy via
027 * {@link DemographicConfiguration};</li>
028 * <li>utility methods for spatial placement such as {@link #hilbertBits()} and
029 * {@link #getHilbertCoords(Integer)}.</li>
030 * </ul>
031 *
032 * <p>
033 * Downstream uses: instances are consulted by model builders and initialisers
034 * during setup. Typical consumers include
035 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultPersonInitialiser} and
036 * {@link io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.AbstractModelBuilder}. Implementations
037 * are commonly generated by Immutables (see
038 * {@link ImmutableSetupConfiguration}).
039 *
040 * @author Rob Challen
041 */
042@Value.Immutable
043@JsonSerialize(as = ImmutableSetupConfiguration.class)
044@JsonDeserialize(as = ImmutableSetupConfiguration.class)
045public interface SetupConfiguration
046                extends Abstraction.Named, Abstraction.Replica, Serializable {
047
048        /**
049         * Default setup configuration used in examples and tests.
050         */
051        public ImmutableSetupConfiguration DEFAULT = ImmutableSetupConfiguration
052                        .builder().setName("default").setInitialImports(30)
053                        .setDemographics(LocationAwareDemography.DEFAULT)
054                        .setNetwork(ErdosReyniConfiguration.DEFAULT).build();
055
056        /**
057         * Demographic configuration.
058         *
059         * <p>
060         * This selects the demographic strategy used when creating persons and when
061         * computing pairwise relationship strengths. Common implementations include:
062         * <ul>
063         * <li>{@link UnstratifiedDemography} — draws strengths from a single
064         * distribution;</li>
065         * <li>{@link AgeStratifiedDemography} — samples ages and adjusts contact
066         * odds by age difference;</li>
067         * <li>{@link LocationAwareDemography} — supplies spatial placement and
068         * proximity based modifiers.</li>
069         * </ul>
070         *
071         * <p>
072         * Demographic implementations are responsible for providing
073         * {@link DemographicConfiguration#createPersonStub} used during setup and
074         * {@link DemographicConfiguration#getRelationshipStrength} used when
075         * composing contact probabilities. If you need richer per‑person data (for
076         * example loading census CSVs) provide a custom Demographic implementation
077         * and register it via Jackson polymorphism.
078         *
079         * @return the demographic configuration used during person creation and
080         *         baselining
081         */
082        DemographicConfiguration getDemographics();
083
084        /**
085         * For sequentially created networks such as Watts‑Strogatz the geographical
086         * location can be decided by the ring position. This will tend to create a
087         * network that has geographical location correlating to network topology.
088         *
089         * <p>
090         * The returned coordinates are normalised to the unit square [0,1]x[0,1] and
091         * are suitable for assigning {@code locationX/locationY} on
092         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.abm.PersonDemographic} during setup. The method
093         * uses a Hilbert curve with bits chosen to provide adequate resolution for
094         * the configured network size.
095         *
096         * @param id the ring position (for example the sequential node index)
097         * @return an X‑Y geographical location (range 0 to 1)
098         */
099        @JsonIgnore
100        default double[] getHilbertCoords(Integer id) {
101                double size = this.getNetwork().getNetworkSize();
102                var hilbert = this.hilbertBits();
103                var tmp = hilbert
104                                .point((long) (id / size * Math.pow(2, hilbert.bits() * 2)));
105                return new double[] { (tmp[0]) / Math.pow(2, hilbert.bits()),
106                                (tmp[1]) / Math.pow(2, hilbert.bits()), };
107        }
108
109        /**
110         * Number of initial cases to seed the outbreak with.
111         *
112         * <p>
113         * Used by {@link io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultPersonInitialiser} to
114         * compute a simple per‑person importation probability during initialisation.
115         * The value represents a coarse seeding strategy; for more sophisticated
116         * seeding (geographically localised or stratified by demographic) supply a
117         * custom initialiser in a composed
118         * {@link io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.AbstractModelBuilder}.
119         *
120         * @return the number of initial imports to seed
121         */
122        Integer getInitialImports();
123
124        /**
125         * Network generation configuration.
126         *
127         * <p>
128         * The returned {@link NetworkConfiguration} defines which graph model is
129         * used to construct the social network during the setup stage. The project
130         * provides a few common implementations:
131         * <ul>
132         * <li>{@link ErdosReyniConfiguration} — classical G(n,p) random graph;</li>
133         * <li>{@link WattsStrogatzConfiguration} — small‑world rewired lattice;</li>
134         * <li>{@link BarabasiAlbertConfiguration} — preferential attachment / scale
135         * free.</li>
136         * </ul>
137         *
138         * <p>
139         * Builders call {@link NetworkConfiguration#generateGraph} passing an empty
140         * JGraphT {@code SimpleGraph<Person,DefaultEdge>} to populate nodes and
141         * edges. To add a new topology implement a new configuration type and
142         * register it with the Jackson polymorphic mapping used by the config
143         * loader.
144         *
145         * @return the network configuration used for agent placement and contact
146         *         construction
147         */
148        NetworkConfiguration getNetwork();
149
150        /**
151         * Utility method to compute a Hilbert curve with bits chosen to provide
152         * adequate resolution for the configured network size. This is used by
153         * {@link #getHilbertCoords(Integer)} to compute spatial coordinates for
154         * agents based on their ring position. The returned curve is 2‑dimensional
155         * and has bits chosen such that the total number of points on the curve is
156         * at least the network size, ensuring a unique coordinate for each agent.
157         *
158         * @return a SmallHilbertCurve instance with bits set for the configured
159         *         network size
160         */
161        @JsonIgnore
162        default SmallHilbertCurve hilbertBits() {
163                double size = this.getNetwork().getNetworkSize();
164                var bits = (int) Math.ceil(0.5 * Math.log(size) / Math.log(2));
165                return HilbertCurve.small().bits(bits).dimensions(2);
166        }
167
168}
